cur = cur->left; } top = s.top(); s.pop(); cur = top->right; }}void InOrder(node *root)//é€’å½’{ if (root->left_child != NULL) { InOrder(root->left_child); } cout << root->data << ' '; if (root->right_child != NULL) { InOrder(root->right_child); }}void InOrderLoop(TreeNode *root)//éžé€’å½’{ std::stack<TreeNode *> s; TreeNode *cur; cur = root; while (cur != NULL || !s.empty()) { while (cur != NULL) { s.push(cur); cur = cur->left; } cur = s.top(); s.pop(); printf("%c ", cur->data); cur = cur->right; }}void PostOrder(node *root)//é€’å½’{ if (root->left_child != NULL) { PostOrder(root->left_child); } if (root->right_child != NULL) { PostOrder(root->right_child); } cout << root->data << ' ';}void PostOrderLoop(TreeNode *root)//éžé€’å½’{ std::stack<TreeNode *> s; TreeNode *cur, *top, *last = NULL; cur = root; while (cur != NULL || !s.empty()) { while (cur != NULL) { s.push(cur); cur = cur->left; } top = s.top(); if (top->right == NULL || top->right == last){ s.pop(); printf("%c ", top->data); last = top; } else { cur = top->right; } }}void dfs(node* root)//æ·±åº¦ä¼˜å…ˆéåŽ†ï¼ˆDepth First Searchï¼ŒDFSï¼Œä¸»è¦æœ‰ä¸‰ç§å­æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå‰ä¸­åŽåºéåŽ†ï¼‰{ stack<node*> q; q.push(root); node *mynode; while (!q.empty()) { mynode = q.front(); q.pop(); cout << mynode->data; num++; if (num < n) cout << ' '; if (mynode->right_child != NULL) q.push(mynode->right_child); if (mynode->left_child != NULL) q.push(mynode->left_child); }}int num = 0;void bfs(node* root)//å¹¿åº¦ä¼˜å…ˆæœç´¢ç®—æ³•ï¼ˆBreadth First Searchï¼‰åˆå«å®½åº¦ä¼˜å…ˆæœç´¢ï¼Œæˆ–æ¨ªå‘ä¼˜å…ˆæœç´¢{ queue<node*> q; q.push(root); node *mynode; while (!q.empty()) { mynode = q.front(); q.pop(); cout << mynode->data; num++; if (num < n) cout << ' '; if (mynode->left_child != NULL) q.push(mynode->left_child); if (mynode->right_child != NULL) q.push(mynode->right_child); }}node *Creat_node(int postL, int postR, int inL, int inR){ if (postL>postR) { return NULL; } node *root = new node; root->data = post[postR]; int i; for ( i = inL; i < inR; i++) { if (inor[i] == post[postR]) break; } int num_left = i - inL;//å·¦å­æ ‘ root->left_child = Creat_node(postL, postL + num_left-1, inL, i-1); root->right_child = Creat_node(postL + num_left, postR - 1, i + 1, inR); return root;}int main() { cin >> n; for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) cin >> post[i]; for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) cin >> inor[i]; node* my_node = Creat_node(0, n - 1, 0, n - 1); cout << "DFS: "; dfs(my_node); cout << endl; cout << "BFS: "; bfs(my_node); cout << endl; cout << "PreOrder: "; PreOrder(my_node); cout << endl; cout << "InOrder: "; InOrder(my_node); cout << endl; cout << "PostOrder: "; PostOrder(my_node); return 0;} ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ’» æ ‘çŠ¶æ•°ç»„ 12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728293031323334353637383940int lowbit(int n){ return n&(-n);} void update(int n,int num){ while(n<=MAX) { TreeArray[n]+=num; n+=lowbit(n); }} int GetSum(int n)//å‰nä¸ªå…ƒç´ çš„å’Œ{ int sum=0; while(n>0) { sum+=TreeArray[n]; n-=lowbit(n); } return sum;} int BinarySearch(int target) //äºŒåˆ†æŸ¥æ‰¾{ int mid; int left = 1, right = MAX_NUM; while (left<=right) { mid = left + (right - left) / 2; if (getsum(mid)<target) left = mid + 1; else right = mid - 1; } cout << left << endl;} ðŸ¤½â€ ä»¥ä¸Šã€‚(ã¥â—â”€â—)ã¥ è½¬è½½è¯·æ³¨æ˜Žï¼šDuankongçš„åšå®¢ Â» ç‚¹å‡»é˜…è¯»åŽŸæ–‡

posts.text: ðŸ’¬ Brief introduction to the TIFF format A TIFF file is, well, a Tagged Image File Format (TIFF). As the name implies, the file itself consists of a whole bunch of 'tags' and corresponding values. For example, all TIFF files are expected to have the ImageWidth and ImageLength tags, whose values are the width and length (height) of the image stored within. A core feature of this format lies in how image data is organized in a physical file. TIFF allows for the image data to be stored in chunks as either 'Tiles' or 'Strips'. You could think of a strip as a tile whose width is the same as the image. The format stores offsets for each of these strips or tiles in an image header. This allows for efficient random access of any chunk in the image. The original TIFF format specification calls for use of 32 bit file offset values. I guess you can imagine where I am going with that bit of information. 32 bits implies a maximum value of 2^32 for any offset. Note that these are offsets from the very beginning of the file. In effect, the 32 bit requirement limits the size of the largest possible TIFF file to be under 4 gigabytes. This was fine for a long time (The earliest TIFF release was in 1986), but we now have more data producers hitting this limit. ðŸ’¦ è¯»å–å›¾ç‰‡ Matlabä¸­imread()æ”¯æŒè¯»å–è¶…è¿‡4GBçš„tiffå›¾åƒã€‚å½“ç„¶ä¹Ÿæ”¯æŒLibTIFFè‡ªå¸¦çš„è¯»å–å‡½æ•°ï¼š å‡½æ•° Function read è¯»å–æ•´ä¸ª TIFF å›¾åƒ readEncodedStrip ä»ŽæŒ‡å®šæ¡å¸¦è¯»å–æ•°æ® readEncodedTile ä»ŽæŒ‡å®šå›¾å—è¯»å–æ•°æ® ðŸ’¨ å†™å…¥å›¾ç‰‡ ä»ŽLibTIFFç‰ˆæœ¬4.0.0å¼€å§‹ï¼Œå…¶åç§»å€¼æ ¼å¼ä½¿ç”¨64ä½è€Œä¸æ˜¯32ä½çš„ï¼Œæ•…åŽé¢ä¹Ÿå«åšBigtiffï¼Œç†è®ºä¸Šæœ€å¤§å¯ä»¥æ”¯æŒ17,179,869,184â€¬GBçš„å›¾ç‰‡ã€‚ ðŸšµ å®žçŽ°æ€è·¯ Matlabä¸­ä»¥ obj.TiffObject = Tiff(obj.Filename, 'w8')æ–¹å¼å¼€å§‹å†™å…¥Bigtiffï¼› ç„¶åŽç»“åˆblockprocå‡½æ•°åˆ†å—å†™å…¥å›¾åƒã€‚ ðŸ™Œ ä»£ç å®žçŽ° å®žçŽ°16ä½ç°åº¦å›¾åƒå†™å…¥ã€‚ ðŸ¤¹â€ å‚è€ƒSteve on Image Processing and MATLABæž„é€ ImageAdapterç±» 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627282930313233343536373839404142434445464748495051525354555657585960616263646566676869707172737475767778798081828384858687888990919293949596979899100101102103104105106107108109 classdef bigTiffWriter < ImageAdapter %BIGTIFFWRITER - A basic image adapter to write Big TIFF files. % % A simple ImageAdapter class implementing a Tiff writer ImageAdapter % object for use with BLOCKPROC. % - Tile dimensions must be multiples of 16. % - Only uint8, RGB input image data is supported. % % Based on "Working with Data in Unsupported Formats" % http://www.mathworks.com/help/toolbox/images/f7-12726.html#bse_q4y-1 % % Example: % %% % % Set file names and obtain size information from input file. % inFile = 'example.tif'; % inFileInfo = imfinfo(inFile); % outFile = 'out.tif'; % %% % % Create an output TIFF file with tile size of 128x128 % tileSize = [128, 128]; % has to be a multiple of 16. % outFileWriter = bigTiffWriter(outFile, inFileInfo(1).Height, inFileInfo(1).Width, tileSize(1), tileSize(2)); % %% % % Now call blockproc to rearrange the color channels. % blockproc(inFile, tileSize, @(b) flipdim(b.data,3), 'Destination', outFileWriter); % outFileWriter.close(); % imshowpair(imread(inFile), imread(outFile),'montage'); % % See also: blockproc, Tiff, Tiff/writeEncodedTile % % Copyright 2013 The MathWorks, Inc. properties(GetAccess = public, SetAccess = private) Filename; TiffObject; TileLength; TileWidth; end methods function obj = bigTiffWriter(fname, imageLength, imageWidth, tileLength, tileWidth) % Constructor validateattributes(fname, {'char'}, {'row'}); validateattributes(imageLength, {'numeric'},{'scalar'}); validateattributes(imageWidth, {'numeric'},{'scalar'}); validateattributes(tileLength, {'numeric'},{'scalar'}); validateattributes(tileWidth, {'numeric'},{'scalar'}); if(mod(tileLength,16)~=0 || mod(tileWidth,16)~=0) error('bigTiffWriter:invalidTileSize',...
